result.markdown: --- title: "[Assess] Bracero Farmworker Case Study" subtitle: "üìç Coachella Valley, CA" date: "September 19, 2025" format: revealjs: theme: - default css: custom.scss transition: fade slide-number: true incremental: false chalkboard: true center: true execute: freeze: auto --- # Class Overview - Centering activity - Setting the stage - Paired coding - Group Debrief # Centering Activity # Setting the Stage - This week's focus is on data tidying and transformation - Using metadata from 90 interviews in the Bracero Archive that I scraped - Important to note that each row represents a person, a life, and a family impacted by the Bracero Program # Let's get Started - Find your pair - Open Posit # First Steps - Import Data - Load packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(readxl) # for loading data library(tidyverse) # for tidying ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # | eval: true # | echo: false bracero <- read_excel("~/Google Drive/My Drive/Teaching/ES-202/data/week_03/bracero_pull.xlsx") ``` ::: # Part II: Today's Goal - Understand data structure - Transform and tidy data for necessary questions - Explore and summarize patterns - Connect it to theoretical understandings of procedural justice ## Our data {.smaller} - 90 rows (interviews) - 6 variables (all `chr` type) - title = Person interviewed - subject = topic of interview - description = summary of interview - date = date of interview - identifier = link to original interview file - language = language interview was conducted in ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(bracero) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Data Types {.smaller} - `chr` is character - `dbl` is double (number) - `int` is an integer - `dttm` is date-time - `fct` is factor Thoughts on what variables we may want to change the data types of? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: # Transforming Data (Columns) {.smaller} - Four functions can change the columns of your data without affecting your rows - mutate(): creates new columns based on existing ones - select(): chooses what columns you want in your dataframe - rename(): changes the names of current columns - relocate(): changes the position of those columns ## mutate() function {.smaller} - We use the mutate function to change the `date` column to a date format. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 7 title subject description date identifier language date_format 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-21 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 5 Inez Rios Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 6 Manuel Enriquez Sa‚Ä¶ Bureau‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 7 Alberto Montes Gon‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 8 Ernesto Espino Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2005-11-12 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## mutate() function (cont.) {.smaller} - We can also use mutate for creating new columns, and we can pair it with additional functions, such as ifelse statements. - Perhaps we were interested in creating a new column that defines whether an interview is from a bracero worker or not. - Note that if we wanted to further classify the subject, we might create a factor column and use the `case_match()` function, rather than an ifelse statement. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> mutate(subject_binary = ifelse(subject %in% c("bracero", "Bracero"), "Bracero", "Non-Bracero" )) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 7 title subject description date identifier language subject_binary 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng Non-Bracero 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 3 Asterio L√≥pez L‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 5 Inez Rios Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng Non-Bracero 6 Manuel Enriquez‚Ä¶ Bureau‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Non-Bracero 7 Alberto Montes ‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 8 Ernesto Espino Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng Non-Bracero 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Tor‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Non-Bracero # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## select() function {.smaller} - Perhaps we'd like to remove the original `date` column from our dataframe. - `select()` can be used to select or deselect columns. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3|7|11"} # select column you don't want bracero |> select(-date) # select columns you do want bracero |> select(title, subject, description, date, identifier, language, date_format) # select columns in a row, except the column you don't want bracero |> select(title:description, identifier:date_format) ``` ::: ## rename() function {.smaller} - sometimes original column names aren't very descriptive, or they're too long. - the `rename()` function can help. - let's rename "title" to something more descriptive. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> rename("interviewee" = "title") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 interviewee subject description date identifier language 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 5 Inez Rios Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 8 Ernesto Espino Son of bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## relocate() function {.smaller} - Say we want the `identifier` column at the very end of the dataframe - `relocate` automatically puts the column at the front, so you have to specify `.after` or `.before`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> relocate(identifier, .after = language) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 title subject description date language identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Inez Rios Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Ernesto Espino Son of bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Put it together {.smaller} - We can put all of these data transformation actions together using the pipe `|>` function ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean <- bracero |> mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) |> select(-date) |> rename("interviewee" = "title") |> relocate(identifier, .after = date_format) head(bracero_clean) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-21 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Inez Rios Interact‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau o‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: # Exercise One - Starting with the `bracero` dataframe, code the following three actions using the `|>` into a new dataframe: - mutate the `date` column to be in a DD-MM-YYYY format called `date_format` - hint: you may need to use the `?as.Date()` helper function - select the `title` , `date_format`, and `description`columns - reorder the remaining columns by alphabetic order # Transforming Data (Rows) - Moving on to rows! - `filter()` is a function that allows you to keep rows of interest (but won't change the order of your rows) - `arrange()` changes the order of your rows (but won't filter for anything) ## filter() function - Use the filter() function to select rows that correspond to values of interest. - Say we're interested in only interviews that are spoken in spanish: - use `==` to filter for a direct match ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(language == "spa") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 75 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Jos√© G. Corral Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Eduardo De Santiago Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-03-03 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Salvador Torres Beltr√°n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Luis Zamudio Villagomez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 65 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## filter() (cont.) {.smaller} - You can also combine multiple conditions: - `>` = greater than - `>=` = greater than or equal to - `<` = less than - `<=` less than or equal to - `==` equal to - `!=` does not equal - Can use `&` to combine conditions - `|` for or - Perhaps we're interested in interviews that took place after 2004 in English: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(date_format >= 2004-01-01 & language == "eng") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 15 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-21 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Inez Rios Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Ernesto Espino Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Rudy Villalobos Depart‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Carol Norquest Jr. Family‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-03 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Eleanor Martin Bookke‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-03-17 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 John Tomlin Farmer "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-23 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Sam S√°nchez Public‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-19 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 El√≠as Bonilla Alliso‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-02 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Socorro O. P√©rez Clerk ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-03-03 https://b‚Ä¶ 11 Laurentina Ramos Ju√°rez Ranche‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-03-02 https://b‚Ä¶ 12 Crisostomo Luna del Angel Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2005-07-25 https://b‚Ä¶ 13 Andy Imutan Activi‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2005-09-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 14 Sally Guti√©rrez McQuinn Bookke‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2005-07-28 https://b‚Ä¶ 15 Consuelo Lerma Sewing "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-03-07 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## filter() and str_detect() - We can also combine filter with str_detect() ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(str_detect(interviewee, "Alberto")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Alberto Magall√≥n Jim√©nez Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-28 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Alberto Mendoza Torres bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2003-09-26 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## arrange() - `arrange()` sorts your rows based on the values in the columns. - If you sort more than one row, it will sort the first variable, and the others will be used to "break ties" - including `desc()` wills sort your column values big to small. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> arrange(date_format, interviewee) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Heriberto Cort√©z Cort√©z Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-05-13 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Homero L√≥pez Ortiz Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-05-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Patricio Corrales Rojas Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-07-02 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Liborio Santiago P√©rez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-07-06 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Gregorio Corrales Rojas Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-07-09 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 H√©ctor Sol√≠s Fuentes Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-07-10 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Rodolfo Cruz Figueroa Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-07-25 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Herminio Quezada Dur√°n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2002-12-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Alfredo Fuentes Soto Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-01-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Inez Rios Interact‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: # Exercise Two 1. Filter the `bracero_clean` dataframe for any interviews that took place before 2005 with an interviewee whose name includes "Guadalupe". 2. Sort the `bracero_clean` data frame in descending order by date. What was the date, how many interviews took place, and who is listed first? 3. Filter the `bracero_clean` dataframe for any interviewees that mention "California". How many interviewees mention California? - If you're interested in reading descriptions, you can type "bracero_clean$description[]" with the row number in brackets to print the description in your environment window. # Grouping Data ## group_by() function ## summarize() # Exercise Three 1. How many Braceros were interviewed in this dataset (i.e., Bracero is the topic)? Use a `group_by` function to count. - Hint: R is case-sensitive. 2. How many non-braceros were interviewed in this dataset? 3. Based on the non-bracero topics, can you create a new factor column that groups the topics into 3-5 factors? - use `mutate()`, and `case_match()` to classify the groups into a new column called `topic_group` 4. Are there any interesting patterns in language spoken among your `topic_groups`? Use a `group_by` and `summarize` function to calculate. # Exercise Four 1. Listen to an [interview with Mr. Cris Luna](https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/138), a Bracero from Ozuluama, Veracruz, Mexico. [interview with Mr. Raymundo Villa](https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/81), an interpreter from Ysleta, Texas who worked with Explore the Bracero archives, and listen to or read the biographical descriptions of interviews in the "Oral History" section. 2. Reflect on the aspects of procedural injustice as they relate to othe Bracero program: -
